timeline.bodyText: Autowiring in the HttpSession makes me nervous - I think it's simpler just to declare an HttpServletRequest as a parameter of getSystemInfo() (you may be able to declare HttpSession as a parameter too, I forget if Spring MVC will populate it automatically). You can get the session from the HttpServletRequest.
timeline.author: rjrudin

replies.bodyText: Just verified, you can just declare HttpSession as a parameter - https://www.logicbig.com/tutorials/spring-framework/spring-web-mvc/http-session-param.html - I think that's the better way to go, also makes testing easier. Note that the session will never be null too.
replies.author: rjrudin

timeline.bodyText: I feel it'd be safer for this to be explicitly named for its purpose today, which is for checking session status, right? So this could be "/websocket/sessionStatus", and we'd want to explicitly list that here instead of allowing anything under "/websocket/" (as we could add another path under "/websocket/" that does require authentication and forget to update this).
timeline.author: rjrudin

replies.bodyText:
There are a lot more endpoints called for setting up WebSockets and they include randomly generated paths, so determining all the patterns that should be permitted isn't really practical.
I was able to remove the WebSockets permitted pattern by refactoring the front-end to not attempt to connect to WebSockets when logged out, which was bring the browser its knees with connection attempts.

timeline.bodyText:
Why do we need a WebSocket to send the session timeout value continuously?
Wouldn't getMaxInactiveInterval always return 300 (5 minutes) in our case?
timeline.author: akshaysonvane

replies.bodyText:
I'm puzzled by that too - this is a constant value. I thought the intent was for the middle tier to send a message when the session expired, and/or when there are N seconds remaining before session expiration.
An HttpSessionListener can be used for sending a message when the session expires.
If there's a requirement for sending a message N seconds before expiration - I'm not sure how to do that. I could imagine some object we store in the HttpSession that waits until N seconds before expiration to send a message. That object would be overridden/reset every time a request is received.
replies.author: rjrudin

replies.bodyText:
As @rjrudin points out, the HtttpSessionListener doesn't allow us to catch the situation where we are N seconds before closing the connection. The only opportunity to catch that is with each request. So with each request, I'm using the interceptor to reset the session count down on the front-end side.
I'll make an update to only send out the update if the session last accessed time was more than a second ago to cut down on some of the chatter.
replies.author: ryanjdew
